replies.bodyText:
So I have these two version of code both ready
1.Provide SplitContext as a mutable field, as the code above
2.Use hashCode and equals to indicate if they're the same Split (not include SplitContext)
kewang1024@376fb8a
(https://github.com/kewang1024/presto/commits/test_pass_cache)
When SourcePartitionedScheduler use SimpleNodeSelector to do scheduling for pending task, we may change some split's SplitContext to cacheable and return those split back to SourcePartitionedScheduler
SourcePartitionedScheduler will evict those split from pendingTask (a split Set)
for

Pro: more straightforward  since we are removing the same split from split set.
Con: Split not immutable any more
2.Pro: Split immutable
Con: seems a little hacky to evict from a set using a different Split (but they're same because we don't include SplitContext in equals and hash method), and possibly cause confusion if we lose context at some point

Also want to know your opinion on it @shixuan-fan @wenleix
replies.author: kewang1024

replies.bodyText: We don't use mutable data structure in our codebase. Otherwise, we can avoid creating SplitContext by directly change the context for HiveSplit
replies.author: highker

replies.bodyText: I agree that an immutable class is easier to reason and understand.
replies.author: shixuan-fan

timeline.bodyText: nit: maybe we'd want a builder pattern for this class? Even though currently there is only one field, a builder pattern makes future work easier to understand.
timeline.author: shixuan-fan

+

+
+    @JsonCreator
+    public SplitContext(@JsonProperty boolean cacheable)

replies.bodyText:
In this case !bucketNodeMap.isDynamic() seems a bit redundant?

if we change bucketNodeMap.getBucketToNode().isPresent() to other function, we may need to keep it
replies.author: kewang1024

timeline.bodyText:
I'm not entirely sure if this is a good predicate since this would cover both of the following cases:

There is initial preferred mapping
There is no initial preferred mapping, but with at least one bucketToNode assignment by calling assignOrUpdateBucketToNode

Based on my understanding on the comment, the second case might not be desired?
timeline.author: shixuan-fan

replies.bodyText:
Yes you're right, both situation could happen.
By saying "the second case might not be desired",  I'm guessing you're referring to the call in SectionExecutionFactory?
if it's the call in SectionExecutionFactory, I think we should be safe, because we call getBucketToNode right after nodePartitioningManager.getBucketNodeMap, there is no situation for assignOrUpdateBucketToNode to happen.
But I understand your concern, maybe your suggestion is to have a different method name to indicate that it's initialized instead of checking the map count?
replies.author: kewang1024

replies.bodyText: Yeah I think if what we want to check is initial preferred mapping exists, let's make it exclusive and explicit :D. Also, the method name might need to be changed to reflect the fact that we are only returning the mapping when there is initial mapping.
replies.author: shixuan-fan

timeline.bodyText: Just out of curiosity, what would happen if bucketNodeMap is updated in DynamicBucketNodeMap (thus stageNodeList is not consistent with DynamicBucketNodeMap#getBucketToNode)?
timeline.author: shixuan-fan

replies.bodyText:
It would be the same behavior as we assign random stageNodeList, when we do scheduling, we would distribute bucket (the bucket that couldn't find its desired bucket) to a random node.
bucketNodeMap being updated in DynamicBucketNodeMap would only happen in DynamicLifespanScheduler, which means it happens when some node/task failed and affinity can't be enforced , thus we have to fall back to random choosing.
So the difference with random stageNodeList, we try best effort to put bucket to their desired node, then fall back to random if affinity can't be achieved.
replies.author: kewang1024

replies.bodyText: for a FixedBucketNodeMap, there are situations of HARD_AFFINITY and NO_PREFERENCE, they both use FixedBucketNodeMap, but cacheable for NO_PREFERENCE is false, cacheable for HARD_AFFINITY is true
replies.author: kewang1024

replies.bodyText: Aha! Thanks for explaining. So I guess in FixedBucketNodeMap it might be reasonable to make cacheable a bucket node map level property then, since there won't be update in the mapping.
replies.author: shixuan-fan

replies.bodyText: But as you suggested, storing the cacheable info in InternalNodeInfo would be a more general way, since DynamicBucketNodeMap could have a mixed List of InternalNodeInfo, we still need to iterate through the list
